questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cock up splint This Image shows the splint is keeping the wrist and fingers in extended position which is used for wrist drop. Wrist drop is caused by radial nerve injury. Radial nerve palsy manifests as an inability to dorsiflex the wrist and digits (wrist drop and finger drop). Numbness occurs on the dorsoradial aspect of the hand and the dorsal aspect of the radial 3 1/2 digits.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- OPTION B : FINGER DYNAMIC SPLINT Immobilization in case of fracture of the proximal phalanx Extensor tendon injuries of the finger Prevention of deformities in rheumatoid arthritis Post operative immobilization OPTION C: Undisplaced Colles' fracture is managed by immobilization in a below-elbow plaster cast for six weeks. Displaced fractures are managed by manipulative reduction followed by immobilization in Colles' cast in palmar flexion, pronation, and ulnar deviation. OPTION D: KNUCKLE BENDER SPLINT Knuckle bender splint is used in cases of ulnar claw hand where ulnar nerve recovery is anticipated. The splint can be used to correct and prevent metacarpophalangeal hyperextension.

questions.text: A 28-yr old man has recently finished a half- marathon. He complains of pain along the anterior and medial aspect of the tibia which increases on jogging & walking for a long time. Plain X-Ray radiograph of the leg was found to be normal. What isthe probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Shin splints The most probable diagnosis in the given scenario is a shin splint or medial tibial syndrome (MTSS). MTSS is a stress injury of the tibia which occurs due to the frequent overuse of lower limbs. It is commonly seen in athletes and military personnel. Exercise-induced pain along the distal two-thirds of the medial tibial border. Since stress injury, the radiograph of the leg appearS normal. Management is mainly conservative with rest and activity modification with less repetitive and load-bearing exercises.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- OPTION A: Nutcracker fracture also occurs in foot (Cuboid bone # associated with Navicular Avulsion #) OPTION C: Jones fracture is fracture at base of 5th metatarsal OPTION D: Lisfranc fracture is fracture at tarso-metatarsal joint

questions.text: The given below instrument is used for:

options.label: C
options.text: Controlled traction of the fracture segment

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Plate holding forcep The given instrument is plate holding forcep This is used to hold the plate to the bone while fixing it with screws

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- OPTION B,C AND D IS NOT THE CORRECT ANSWER

Table:

#MANTRA orthopedic instrument PERIOSTEAL ELEVATOR CURETTE OSTEOTOME BONE GAUGE BONE NIBBLER BONE AND PLATE HOLDING FORCEP

questions.text: A child presents with difficulty in walking. On biopsy of the hip,some cells with grooved nuclei and eosinophilic cytoplasm are present. Which investigation would you order next?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cd1a IHC Lytic lesion with hemorrhage is a classical feature of brown tumor which is seen in hyperparathyroidism. So serum PTH levels would confirm the diagnosis. Histopathologically, both chondroblastoma and langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH) have cells with grooved nuclei with eosinophilic cytoplasm. Therefore, to distinguish between them the next step Would be to obtain a CD1a marker which would be positive in LCH. The specific markers for LCH are CD1a langerin (CD207). MRI can be done in the case of chondroblastoma, but it should precede biopsy. Thus, the best option in this case would be to obtain a CD1a marker.

Highyeild:

SKELETAL AND RDIOLOGICAL MANIFESTATION OF LANGERHAN’S CELL HISTIOCYTOSIS Skull: Solitary or multiple punched out lytic lesion without sclerotic rim. Double contour or beveled edge appearance may be seen due to asymmetrical involvement of the inner and outer table (hole within a hole sign). Button sequestra representing residual bone. Geographic skull. SPINE: VERTEBRA PLANA: It is the most common cause of vertebra plana in children ,mostly seen in thoracic spine. Mandible: Irregular radiolucent areas mostly involving superficial alveolar bone. Floating tooth:loss of lamina dura. Long Bones: Permeative and aggressive appearing lesions occur Mainly involves diaphysis or meta diaphysis Endosteal scalloping,Periosteal reaction(in healing phase),cortical thinning,intracortical tunneling and associated soft tissue mass can be seen.

questions.text: A 30 year old male, otherwise healthy presented with right sided periscapular and shoulder pain. The pain increased by continuous overhead activity and downward traction such as carrying heavy objects. This further lead to numbness of the right hand. The patient was asked to perform the test demonstrated in the Image. What is the test?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Roos test The test performed is roo’s test. It is also referred to as the elevated arm stress test(EAST) This is a test performed to detect thoracic outlet syndrome Neurogenic. Ask the patient to abduct arm , externally rotate the hand and flex the elbow. Now ask the patient to flex and extend the fingers for few minutes If the patient develops ischemic pain, weakness of the arm, tingling or numbness in the arm is called positive test. Minor fatigue and distress are not a positive test.

Highyeild:

THORACIC OUTLET SYNDROME It is a neurovascular syndrome caused due to the compression of the lower trunk of brachial plexus (c8 and T1) and subclavian vessels in the thoracic outlet between the clavicle,the first rib and the scalene muscles CLINICAL FEATURES DUE TO COMPRESSION OF BRACHIAL PLEXUS: Pain and paresthesia along the ulnar aspect of the arm subclavian vessel: Cyanosis,cold fingers,pallor and Raynaud’s phenomenon PROVOCATIVE TEST ADSON'S TEST Adson's test: The examiner locates the radial pulse while arm is held in extension, external rotation, and slight abduction. The patient is instructed to take a deep breath and turn head towards the test arm while extending the neck. This manoeuvre will tense the anterior and middle scalenes. If there is outlet obstruction, the radial pulse will get diminished or absent on that side. HALSTEAD MANEUVER (REVERSE ADSON’S) Halstead maneuver (reverse Adson's): The examiner palpates the radial pulse and applies downward traction on the tested extremity while the patient's neck is hyperextended and rotated to the opposite side. Diminished or absent pulse indicates a positive test. WRIGHT’S HYPERABDUCTION TEST: Wright's hyperabduction test: The examiner palpates the radial pulse and hyper-abducts the arm. The patient takes a deep breath and may rotate or extend his neck for additional effect. Absence of pulse indicates a positive test. ROOS TEST Roos test: The patient abducts the shoulders to 90 degrees and flexes the elbow to 90 degrees. The patient is made to open and close the hand slowly for three minutes. The test is positive if the patient is unable to complete the test or experiences cramping, pain, numbness, on the affected side.

questions.text: The test performed in the following Image is?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Allen’s test The test performed in the given video is a modification of Allen’s test It is useful in identifying the adequacy of radial and ulnar collateral blood flow to the hand. This test is mainly done prior to radial artery cannulation and drawing blood for ABG analysis. In this we ask the patient to make a fist and we compress both the ulnar and radial artery Then ask the patient to release the fist. The hand will appear pale as the circulation is blocked Now release radial artery, if the radial artery is competent then the hand will turn red, if not it will remain pale Now release ulnar artery and the hand turns red, it suggests that the circulation is depended on ulnar artery

Highyeild:

Modified Allen's Test The radial and ulnar arteries are occluded by firm pressure while the fist is clenched until the hand blanches The hand is opened and the pressure is released from the ulnar artery Colour should return within 15 seconds to imply adequate arterial circulation

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- OPTION B,C AND D IS NOT THE CORRECT ANSWER

The patient is instructed to take a deep breath and turn head towards the test arm while extending the neck. This manoeuvre will tense the anterior and middle scalenes. If there is outlet obstruction, the radial pulse will get diminished or absent on that side. HALSTEAD MANEUVER (REVERSE ADSON’S) Halstead maneuver (reverse Adson's): The examiner palpates the radial pulse and applies downward traction on the tested extremity while the patient's neck is hyperextended and rotated to the opposite side. Diminished or absent pulse indicates a positive test. WRIGHT’S HYPERABDUCTION TEST: Wright's hyperabduction test: The examiner palpates the radial pulse and hyper-abducts the arm. The patient takes a deep breath and may rotate or extend his neck for additional effect. Absence of pulse indicates a positive test. The test is positive if the patient is unable to complete the test or experiences cramping, pain, numbness, on the affected side.

questions.text: A male brought to the casualty after he met with an accident. He was having comminuted fracture in the lower end of femur. His distal pulses were not palpable so a vascular surgeon decided to explore. So the resident did the following procedure given below the Image. What is the name of the fixator?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Rail fixator The above image shows a rail fixator. In this external fixator,multiple pins are inserted into the bone. These pins are then attached to different blocks which can move over a track or rail.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A: In K-wire fixation, we do not use the rail stabilizer(black colour) Option B: interlocking nails are not preferred for comminuted fracture of lower end of femur, as the surgeon decided to open and explore Option D: Ilizarov fixators have rings

Table:

#MANTRA TENSION BAND WIRING A tension band wire is a form of internal fixation used to convert distraction forces into compression forces, promoting bone healing. It is used in Fracture patella Fracture olecranon Fracture greater trochanter Fracture greater trochanter

questions.text: A boy fell from the height on his outstretched hand. The X-ray is similar to the one shown below. The most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Galeazzi fracture Fracture in the shaft of distal radius with dislocation of distal radio-ulnar joint is called Galeazzi fracture. The given X-ray reveals an oblique fracture in the lower third of the radius with dislocation of the distal radio-ulnar joint, which is diagnostic of Galeazzi fracture-dislocation Patients present with pain, swelling and deformity at the lower end of the radius On examination, the disruption of the radio-ulnar joint can be elicited by pressing the lower end of the ulna. The ulna moves down and comes back like the key of a piano (piano-key sign)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- OPTION B: Rolando's fracture: Intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y configuration. OPTION C: COLLE’S FRACTURE:. Colle's fracture: Extra-articular fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation of the distal bone fragment OPTION D: Fracture of shaft of proximal ulna with dislocation of proximal radio-ulnar joint is called Monteggia’s fracture
